message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Bacterial species rarely work together
Paper Abstract: Competition is prevalent and could be harnessed as an alternative to antibiotics
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's comprehensive information about antibiotics from the search results:

## Definition and Meaning

In current usage, the term "antibiotic" is applied to any medication that kills bacteria or inhibits their growth, regardless of whether that medication is produced by a microorganism or not.

## Uses

Antibiotics are used to treat or prevent bacterial infections, and sometimes protozoan infections.

## Types

The highest division between antibiotics is bactericidal and bacteriostatic. Bactericidals kill bacteria directly, whereas bacteriostatics prevent them from dividing.

## Historical Background

The earliest use of antibiotics was found in northern Sudan, where ancient Sudanese societies as early as 350–550 CE were systematically consuming antibiotics as part of their diet. Chemical analyses of Nubian skeletons show consistent, high levels of tetracycline, a powerful antibiotic. Researchers believe they were brewing beverages from grain fermented with Streptomyces, a bacterium that naturally produces tetracycline.(no content)Antibiotics revolutionized medicine in the 20th century.

## Major Concern: Antibiotic Resistance

The effectiveness and easy access to antibiotics have also led to their overuse and some bacteria have evolved resistance to them. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR), a naturally occurring process, is primarily driven by the misuse and overuse of antimicrobials.(no content)Each year, nearly 5 million deaths are associated with AMR globally.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "biological competition"

Links: [{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Interspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interspecific_competition"},{"title":"Intraspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intraspecific_competition"},{"title":"Competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition"},{"title":"Biological interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_interaction"},{"title":"International Biology Olympiad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Biology_Olympiad"},{"title":"Natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"International Genetically Engineered Machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Genetically_Engineered_Machine"},{"title":"Competition–colonization trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition–colonization_trade-off"}]

Here are the search results for "biological competition":

## Overview

In the study of community ecology, competition within and between members of a species is an important biological interaction and one of many interacting biotic and abiotic factors that affect community structure, species diversity, and population dynamics.

## Types of Competition

There are three major mechanisms of competition: interference, exploitation, and apparent competition (in order from most direct to least direct). Additionally, competition among members of the same species is known as intraspecific competition, while competition between individuals of different species is known as interspecific competition.

### Intraspecific Competition
Intraspecific competition is an interaction in population ecology whereby members of the same species compete for limited resources, which leads to a reduction in fitness for both individuals, but the more fit individual survives and is able to reproduce.

### Interspecific Competition
Interspecific competition is a form of competition in which individuals of different species compete for the same resources in an ecosystem (e.g. food or living space).

## Mechanisms

**Interference Competition:** During interference competition, also called contest competition, organisms interact directly by fighting for scarce resources.

**Exploitation Competition:** Exploitative competition, also referred to as resource competition, is a form of competition in which one species consumes and either reduces or depletes a resource. A good example is found in aphid species competing over the sap in plant phloem, where each aphid species uses some of the resource, leaving less for competing species.

## Evolutionary Significance

According to evolutionary theory, competition within and between species for resources is important in natural selection.

Here are the search results for "biological competition":

## Overview

In the study of community ecology, competition within and between members of a species is an important biological interaction and one of many interacting biotic and abiotic factors that affect community structure, species diversity, and population dynamics.

## Types of Competition

There are three major mechanisms of competition: interference, exploitation, and apparent competition (in order from most direct to least direct). Additionally, competition among members of the same species is known as intraspecific competition, while competition between individuals of different species is known as interspecific competition.

### Intraspecific Competition
Intraspecific competition is an interaction in population ecology whereby members of the same species compete for limited resources, which leads to a reduction in fitness for both individuals, but the more fit individual survives and is able to reproduce.

### Interspecific Competition
Interspecific competition is a form of competition in which individuals of different species compete for the same resources in an ecosystem (e.g. food or living space).

## Mechanisms

**Interference Competition:** During interference competition, also called contest competition, organisms interact directly by fighting for scarce resources.

**Exploitation Competition:** Exploitative competition, also referred to as resource competition, is a form of competition in which one species consumes and either reduces or depletes a resource. A good example is found in aphid species competing over the sap in plant phloem, where each aphid species uses some of the resource, leaving less for competing species.

## Evolutionary Significance

According to evolutionary theory, competition within and between species for resources is important in natural selection.

Links: [{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Microbial cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_cooperation"},{"title":"Type VI secretion system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_VI_secretion_system"},{"title":"Polymorphic toxins - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymorphic_toxins"},{"title":"Competition–colonization trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition–colonization_trade-off"},{"title":"Kill the Winner hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kill_the_Winner_hypothesis"},{"title":"Sarah Coulthurst - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Coulthurst"},{"title":"Interspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interspecific_competition"},{"title":"Antimicrobial resistance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimicrobial_resistance"},{"title":"Streamlining theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streamlining_theory"}]

I've performed a web search for "bacterial competition." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Bacterial Competition

Competition is an interaction between organisms or species in which both require one or more resources that are in limited supply (such as food, water, or territory). Competition lowers the fitness of both organisms involved since the presence of one of the organisms always reduces the amount of the resource available to the other.

## Types of Bacterial Competition

There are three major mechanisms of competition: interference, exploitation, and apparent competition (in order from most direct to least direct). Interference and exploitation competition can be classed as "real" forms of competition, while apparent competition is not, as organisms do not share a resource, but instead share a predator.

## Competitive Strategies in Bacteria

Bacteria employ several sophisticated competition strategies:

1. **Toxin Production**: Bacteria have evolved several systems to outcompete their neighbors by poisoning them through a contact-dependent killing (including effectors of type V and VI secretion systems) or the release of soluble toxins (including colicins) in the environment.

2. **Resource Utilization**: In a mixed community, different bacterial species have been found to adapt to different food sources, including the waste products of other species, in order to stave off unnecessary competition. This allows heightened efficiency for the community as a whole.

3. **Trade-offs**: In a two-species artificial metacommunity of motile strains on-chip, bacteria Escherichia coli is a fugitive species, whereas Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a slower colonizer but superior competitor.

This highlights the diverse mechanisms bacteria use to compete for limited resources in their environments.

I've performed a web search for "bacteria". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Bacteria are ubiquitous, mostly free-living organisms often consisting of one biological cell and constitute a large domain of prokaryotic microorganisms.(no content)Typically a few micrometres in length, bacteria were among the first life forms to appear on Earth and are present in most of its habitats.

## Characteristics

Unlike cells of animals and other eukaryotes, bacterial cells contain circular chromosomes, do not contain a nucleus and rarely harbour membrane-bound organelles.(no content)The bacterial cell wall differs from that of all other organisms by the presence of peptidoglycan which is located immediately outside of the cell membrane, made up of a polysaccharide backbone of alternating N-Acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine residues, and is responsible for the rigidity of the bacterial cell wall and determination of cell shape.

## Bacteria in the Human Body

Humans carry vast numbers (approximately 10^13 to 10^14) of bacteria, with most in the gut, though there are many on the skin.(no content)Most of the bacteria in and on the body are harmless or rendered so by the protective effects of the immune system, and many are beneficial, particularly the ones in the gut.

## Pathogenic Bacteria and Disease

Several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, anthrax, leprosy, tuberculosis, tetanus and bubonic plague.

## Practical Applications

Bacteria are important in sewage treatment and the breakdown of oil spills, the production of cheese and yogurt through fermentation, the recovery of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector, as well as in biotechnology and the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals.

Several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, anthrax, leprosy, tuberculosis, tetanus and bubonic plague.

## Practical Applications

Bacteria are important in sewage treatment and the breakdown of oil spills, the production of cheese and yogurt through fermentation, the recovery of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector, as well as in biotechnology and the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals.

I've performed a web search for "bacteria". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Bacteria are ubiquitous, mostly free-living organisms often consisting of one biological cell and constitute a large domain of prokaryotic microorganisms.(no content)Typically a few micrometres in length, bacteria were among the first life forms to appear on Earth and are present in most of its habitats.

## Characteristics

Unlike cells of animals and other eukaryotes, bacterial cells contain circular chromosomes, do not contain a nucleus and rarely harbour membrane-bound organelles.(no content)The bacterial cell wall differs from that of all other organisms by the presence of peptidoglycan which is located immediately outside of the cell membrane, made up of a polysaccharide backbone of alternating N-Acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine residues, and is responsible for the rigidity of the bacterial cell wall and determination of cell shape.

## Bacteria in the Human Body

Humans carry vast numbers (approximately 10^13 to 10^14) of bacteria, with most in the gut, though there are many on the skin.(no content)Most of the bacteria in and on the body are harmless or rendered so by the protective effects of the immune system, and many are beneficial, particularly the ones in the gut.

## Pathogenic Bacteria and Disease

Several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, anthrax, leprosy, tuberculosis, tetanus and bubonic plague.

## Practical Applications

Bacteria are important in sewage treatment and the breakdown of oil spills, the production of cheese and yogurt through fermentation, the recovery of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector, as well as in biotechnology and the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Bacterial species rarely work together." Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` (the paper proposes using bacterial competition as an alternative to antibiotics)

**Identified Triples (5 total):**

1. **Bacteria** (task) - Uses: The core subject of study in the paper.
2. **Competition (biology)** (concept) - Uses: The fundamental ecological process being investigated.
3. **Antibiotic** (artifact) - Uses: The conventional treatment method being discussed as a comparison point.
4. **Antimicrobial resistance** (concept) - Uses: The motivation for seeking alternative therapeutic approaches.
5. **Alternative antibiotic therapy using bacterial competition** (concept) - Proposes: The novel approach introduced by the paper.

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation has passed successfully. The file `triples_output.json` now contains the complete knowledge graph representation of the paper with:
- Correct paper type classification
- All relevant entities with proper types
- Appropriate use/proposes relationships
- Valid Wikipedia URLs
- Meaningful relevance descriptions

Sources:

- [Competition (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology))
- [Antibiotic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antibiotic)
- [Antimicrobial resistance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimicrobial_resistance)
